channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Anti-Chinese Protests End in Vietnam
item.description: Police guards around Chinese buildings in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City effectively ended a week of protests over a Chinese oil rig in disputed South China Sea waters.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: North Korea Admits to ‘Serious’ Building Collapse
item.description: A South Korean official said Sunday that a 23-story apartment building, housing dozens of families, had collapsed in Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Deep Ties, Tested on Mexico’s Border
item.description: Laredo, Tex., along the Mexican border, where Interstate 35 begins its path, faces extreme challenges to meld two cultures, an evolution occurring in cities and towns nationwide.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: A view of Nuevo Laredo from across the Rio Grande River in Laredo.

item.title: Outlasting Dynasties, Now Emerging From Soot
item.description: Chinese officials and preservationists have embarked on an ambitious effort to protect historic sites that could become a model for saving antiquities elsewhere.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The nearly 50-foot Buddha is being restored.

item.title: Talks in East Aim to Ease Tensions in Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian officials on Saturday held more negotiations aimed at ending the country’s political crisis, this time in the region torn by pro-Russian separatism.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Libyans Told to Leave City Amid Clashes
item.description: Troops in Benghazi prepared for a new assault on Islamist militias a day after heavy fighting in the city.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Ukrainians Working in Italy Do What They Can to Help
item.description: Nearly 200,000 Ukrainians work in Italy, and being far from home during a time of deep uncertainty has led some to look for ways to lend support.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mar’yana Tril came from Ukraine to work in Rome. She took a first-aid course to prepare her to help wounded fighters in Kiev.

item.title: U.N. Seeking More Ways to Distribute Aid in Syria
item.description: The United Nations is under pressure to ratchet up aid to nongovernmental organizations that can operate in the vast swaths of Syria under opposition control.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Activists said forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad attacked Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday.

item.title: Fare Dodging Is an Organized Rebellion in Stockholm, and It’s Winning
item.description: A group offers instructional videos on slipping through station gates without paying, and it uses monthly dues to cover fines for any members who are nabbed.
item.dc:creator: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Berthelsen, right, slipping through subway station gates in Stockholm last month.

item.title: Vietnamese Officials Intolerant of Violence as Standoff With China Continues
item.description: Authorities said that further violence over a dispute with China would not be tolerated, declaring that more than 300 people involved in last week’s attacks on foreign-owned businesses would be prosecuted.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: West African Nations Set Aside Their Old Suspicions to Combat Boko Haram
item.description: The leaders of five West African countries, including Nigeria, met Saturday with Western officials and agreed to cooperate in combating the extremist Islamist group.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: In Taking Crimea, Putin Gains a Sea of Fuel Reserves
item.description: Russia acquired not just a peninsula, but a maritime zone and the rights to tap its seabed for oil and gas reserves potentially worth trillions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:credit: RIA Novosti/Alexei Druzhinin, via Pool, via Reuters
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visiting a Lukoil oil platform in the Caspian Sea in 2010.

item.title: As Turkish Mine Yields the Last Body, Recriminations Remain
item.description: The death toll in Turkey’s worst mining accident rose to 301 people, as final recovery efforts were hampered by a fire and a gas leak.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man waited for news about a missing family member near the coal mine in Soma, Turkey, on Saturday.

item.title: Victor in India Promises to Make Country Strong
item.description: Narendra Modi, the man expected to become India’s next prime minister, swept into New Delhi on Saturday morning and promised he “will try to make India self-reliant and strong.”
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Narendra Modi greeted supporters outside the Bharatiya Janata Party's headquarters in Delhi, on Saturday.

item.title: 54 Bodies Are Recovered After River Ferry Sinks During a Storm in Bangladesh
item.description: When the search was called off, hundreds of relatives and local residents protested at the scene of the accident, forcing the authorities to continue to look for bodies.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing : Germany: The Flight of the Iguana
item.description: A bizarre cargo of more than 80 exotic reptiles, including four horned vipers and an iguana, attracted the attention of an alert customs official at Frankfurt Airport this week.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: The Lede: Images of Turkish Official Kicking Protester Fuel Anger Online
item.description: The behavior of senior officials in Turkey remained under the social media microscope on Thursday, as an aide to the prime minister acknowledged that he did kick a protester the day before.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Yusuf Yerkel, an aide to Turkey's prime minister, was photographed kicking a man during protests on Wednesday in the city of Soma.

item.title: Air Crash in Laos Kills Top Officials for Security
item.description: Two key figures in the security apparatus of the authoritarian government were among those killed, Laotian diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Rescue workers searched the site of a plane crash near Nadee village in Xiangkhouang province in Laos on Saturday.

item.title: India Ink: Congress’s Rank and File Lament Demise of Party Once Beloved
item.description: Theories abound for the Indian National Congress’s reversal of fortunes, but workers gathered at the party headquarters during the vote count said the culture of the leadership had changed.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: American Missionary Killed
item.description: An American missionary in his 70s who had moved to Haiti in the wake of the 2010 earthquake was stabbed to death in Port-au-Prince, the capital, the police and friends said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing : Bangladesh: Ferry Death Toll Rises
item.description: A ferry that capsized during a storm in central Bangladesh, killing at least 29 people and possibly many more, was probably overcrowded when it went down on Thursday, the authorities said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Boy Kills a Jailed Man Who Was Accused of Blasphemy
item.description: A teenage Pakistani boy walked into a police station on Friday and shot dead a 65-year-old man accused of blasphemy.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Jean-Luc Dehaene, Former Prime Minister of Belgium, Is Dead at 73
item.description: Mr. Dehaene, a member of the Flemish Christian Democratic Party, became prime minister in March 1992.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Key Figure in Libya’s Revolution Leads Attack on Islamists
item.description: A former general gained support from members of the army in eastern Libya and killed two dozen people in and around Benghazi, according to news reports.
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Quick History: Democracy Triumphs in India, but Falters Again in Ukraine
item.description: An orderly, large-scale election contrasts with crises in Ukraine, Thailand and Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: People waited to cast their votes on Monday at a polling station in Jaunpur, in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, India.
